FRED Releases

Sam Boysel

2022-08-22

Source: vignettes/fredr-releases.Rmd
fredr-releases.Rmd

Introduction 

library(fredr)

This vignette is intended to introduce the user to fredr functions for the Releases endpoint of the FRED API.

FRED series are added to the FRED database over time in releases. Each FRED release is assigned an integer identifier. The following examples illustrate usage of the Releases endpoint functions in fredr.

Get all releases of economic data

The function fredr_releases() returns a set of all FRED releases matching the request. The data returned is a tibble in which each row represents a FRED release. The default call returns all FRED releases:

fredr_releases()
#> # A tibble: 307 × 7
#>       id realtime_start realtime_end name                    press…¹ link  notes
#>    <int> <chr>          <chr>        <chr>                   <lgl>   <chr> <chr>
#>  1     9 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   Advance Monthly Sales … TRUE    http… "The…
#>  2    10 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   Consumer Price Index    TRUE    http…  NA  
#>  3    11 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   Employment Cost Index   TRUE    http…  NA  
#>  4    13 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   G.17 Industrial Produc… TRUE    http…  NA  
#>  5    14 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   G.19 Consumer Credit    TRUE    http…  NA  
#>  6    15 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   G.5 Foreign Exchange R… TRUE    http…  NA  
#>  7    17 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   H.10 Foreign Exchange … TRUE    http…  NA  
#>  8    18 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   H.15 Selected Interest… TRUE    http…  NA  
#>  9    19 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   H.3 Aggregate Reserves… TRUE    http… "The…
#> 10    20 2022-08-21     2022-08-21   H.4.1 Factors Affectin… TRUE    http…  NA  
#> # … with 297 more rows, and abbreviated variable name ¹​press_release

Get release dates for all releases of economic data.

The function fredr_releases_dates() returns a set of release dates for all FRED releases. The data returned is a tibble where each row represents a release date for a release. For example, to get all release dates (up to the limit of 1000) ordered by descending release date:

fredr_releases_dates()
#> # A tibble: 1,000 × 3
#>    release_id release_name                                          date      
#>         <int> <chr>                                                 <chr>     
#>  1         72 Daily Treasury Inflation-Indexed Securities           2022-08-22
#>  2        101 FOMC Press Release                                    2022-08-22
#>  3        504 Historical Overnight AMERIBOR Unsecured Interest Rate 2022-08-22
#>  4        484 Key ECB Interest Rates                                2022-08-22
#>  5        287 Nikkei Indexes                                        2022-08-22
#>  6        445 Secured Overnight Financing Rate Data                 2022-08-22
#>  7        483 SOFR Averages and Index Data                          2022-08-22
#>  8        492 SONIA Interest Rate Benchmark                         2022-08-22
#>  9        305 Swiss National Bank Monthly Statistical Bulletin      2022-08-22
#> 10        441 Coinbase Cryptocurrencies                             2022-08-21
#> # … with 990 more rows

To instead order the results by ascending release ID:

fredr_releases_dates(
  sort_order = "asc",
  order_by = "release_id"
)
#> # A tibble: 1,000 × 3
#>    release_id release_name                                       date      
#>         <int> <chr>                                              <chr>     
#>  1          9 Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services 2022-01-14
#>  2          9 Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services 2022-02-16
#>  3          9 Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services 2022-03-16
#>  4          9 Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services 2022-04-14
#>  5          9 Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services 2022-04-25
#>  6          9 Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services 2022-05-17
#>  7          9 Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services 2022-06-15
#>  8          9 Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services 2022-07-15
#>  9          9 Advance Monthly Sales for Retail and Food Services 2022-08-17
#> 10         10 Consumer Price Index                               2022-01-12
#> # … with 990 more rows

Get a release of economic data

The function fredr_release() returns data for a single FRED release specified by release_id. The data returned is a tibble where each row represents the specified release. For example, to get release data for the Employment Cost Index release:

fredr_release(release_id = 11L)
#> # A tibble: 1 × 6
#>      id realtime_start realtime_end name                  press_release link    
#>   <int> <chr>          <chr>        <chr>                 <lgl>         <chr>   
#> 1    11 2022-08-22     2022-08-22   Employment Cost Index TRUE          http://…

Get release dates for a single release of economic data

The function fredr_release_dates() returns a set of release dates for a single FRED release specified by release_id. The data returned is a tibble where each row represents a release date for the release specified. For example, to get release dates for the Employment Cost Index release:

fredr_release_dates(release_id = 11L)
#> # A tibble: 115 × 2
#>    release_id date      
#>         <int> <chr>     
#>  1         11 1996-10-29
#>  2         11 1997-01-28
#>  3         11 1997-04-29
#>  4         11 1997-07-29
#>  5         11 1997-10-28
#>  6         11 1998-01-27
#>  7         11 1998-04-30
#>  8         11 1998-07-30
#>  9         11 1998-10-29
#> 10         11 1999-01-28
#> # … with 105 more rows

Get the series in a release of economic data

The function fredr_release_series() returns a set of series belonging to the FRED release specified by release_id. The data returned is a tibble where each row represents a series in the release specified. For example, to get series in the Employment Cost Index release:

fredr_release_series(release_id = 10L)
#> # A tibble: 1,000 × 16
#>    id       realti…¹ realt…² title obser…³ obser…⁴ frequ…⁵ frequ…⁶ units units…⁷
#>    <chr>    <chr>    <chr>   <chr> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
#>  1 CPIAPPNS 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1914-1… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  2 CPIAPPSL 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1947-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  3 CPIAUCNS 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1913-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  4 CPIAUCSL 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1947-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  5 CPIEDUNS 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1993-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  6 CPIEDUSL 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1993-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  7 CPIENGNS 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1957-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  8 CPIENGSL 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1957-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  9 CPIFABNS 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1967-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#> 10 CPIFABSL 2022-08… 2022-0… Cons… 1967-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#> # … with 990 more rows, 6 more variables: seasonal_adjustment <chr>,
#> #   seasonal_adjustment_short <chr>, last_updated <chr>, popularity <int>,
#> #   group_popularity <int>, notes <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
#> #   ¹​realtime_start, ²​realtime_end, ³​observation_start, ⁴​observation_end,
#> #   ⁵​frequency, ⁶​frequency_short, ⁷​units_short

Note the parameters available to filter series belonging to a release:

fredr_release_series(
  release_id = 10L,
  filter_variable = "frequency",
  filter_value = "Monthly",
  order_by = "popularity",
  sort_order = "desc",
  limit = 10L
)
#> # A tibble: 10 × 16
#>    id        realt…¹ realt…² title obser…³ obser…⁴ frequ…⁵ frequ…⁶ units units…⁷
#>    <chr>     <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr>  
#>  1 CPIAUCSL  2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1947-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  2 CPILFESL  2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1957-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  3 CUSR0000… 2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1953-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  4 CUUR0000… 2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1914-1… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  5 CPIAUCNS  2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1913-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  6 CUUR0000… 2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1913-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  7 CUUR0000… 2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1947-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  8 CUSR0000… 2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1953-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#>  9 CPIENGSL  2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1957-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#> 10 CUSR0000… 2022-0… 2022-0… Cons… 1983-0… 2022-0… Monthly M       Inde… Index …
#> # … with 6 more variables: seasonal_adjustment <chr>,
#> #   seasonal_adjustment_short <chr>, last_updated <chr>, popularity <int>,
#> #   group_popularity <int>, notes <chr>, and abbreviated variable names
#> #   ¹​realtime_start, ²​realtime_end, ³​observation_start, ⁴​observation_end,
#> #   ⁵​frequency, ⁶​frequency_short, ⁷​units_short

Get the FRED tags for a release

The function fredr_release_tags() returns a set of tags assigned to series belonging to the FRED release specified by release_id. The data returned is a tibble where each row represents a tag. For example, to get the geographic tags assigned to series in the Consumer Price Index release:

fredr_release_tags(
  release_id = 10L,
  tag_group_id = "geo",
  order_by = "popularity",
  sort_order = "desc"
)
#> # A tibble: 66 × 6
#>    name  group_id notes                    created               popul…¹ serie…²
#>    <chr> <chr>    <chr>                    <chr>                   <int>   <int>
#>  1 usa   geo      United States of America 2012-02-27 10:18:19-…     100    4534
#>  2 ca    geo      California               2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      63     218
#>  3 tx    geo      Texas                    2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      60     208
#>  4 fl    geo      Florida                  2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      59     136
#>  5 ny    geo      New York                 2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      55      94
#>  6 ga    geo      Georgia (U.S. state)     2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      52     106
#>  7 pa    geo      Pennsylvania             2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      51     252
#>  8 il    geo      Illinois                 2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      51     170
#>  9 va    geo      Virginia                 2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      50     100
#> 10 wa    geo      Washington (state)       2012-02-27 10:18:19-…      50     160
#> # … with 56 more rows, and abbreviated variable names ¹​popularity,
#> #   ²​series_count

Get the related FRED tags for one or more FRED tags within a release

The function fredr_release_related_tags() returns a set of tags assigned to series belonging to the FRED release specified by release_id that are related to tags specified in tag_names. The data returned is a tibble where each row represents a related tag. For example, to get frequency tags assigned to series in the Consumer Price Index release that are also related to the tag bls and not the annual tag:

fredr_release_related_tags(
  release_id = 10L,
  tag_names = "bls",
  tag_group_id = "freq",
  exclude_tag_names = "annual",
  order_by = "popularity",
  sort_order = "desc"
)
#> # A tibble: 2 × 6
#>   name       group_id notes created                popularity series_count
#>   <chr>      <chr>    <chr> <chr>                       <int>        <int>
#> 1 monthly    freq     ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19-06         95         2132
#> 2 semiannual freq     ""    2012-02-27 10:18:19-06         32         1862

Get the sources for a release of economic data

The function fredr_release_sources() returns a set of FRED sources for the FRED release specified by release_id. The data returned is a tibble where each row represents a source. For example, to get the sources for the Consumer Price Index release:

fredr_release_sources(release_id = 10L)
#> # A tibble: 1 × 5
#>      id realtime_start realtime_end name                            link        
#>   <int> <chr>          <chr>        <chr>                           <chr>       
#> 1    22 2022-08-22     2022-08-22   U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics https://www…

Get release table trees for a given release

The function fredr_release_tables() returns a set of FRED release table trees for the FRED release specified by release_id. The data returned is a tibble where each row represents an element of the table tree’s children: the column name gives the element ID and the column value stores data nodes for the element (e.g. element ID, release ID, parent ID, element type, element name, children, etc.). For example, to get the table tree for the Consumer Price Index release:

cpi_tbl <- fredr_release_tables(release_id = 10L)
cpi_tbl
#> # A tibble: 2 × 2
#>   name  value           
#>   <chr> <list>          
#> 1 34481 <named list [9]>
#> 2 36712 <named list [9]>

The above table has two elements: 34481 and 36712. Inspect an element (a list) by selecting its row and unnesting the row element value using tibble::deframe():

library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(tibble)

cpi_tbl %>%
  slice(2) %>%
  deframe()
#> $`36712`
#> $`36712`$element_id
#> [1] 36712
#> 
#> $`36712`$release_id
#> [1] 10
#> 
#> $`36712`$series_id
#> NULL
#> 
#> $`36712`$parent_id
#> NULL
#> 
#> $`36712`$line
#> NULL
#> 
#> $`36712`$type
#> [1] "section"
#> 
#> $`36712`$name
#> [1] "Consumer Price Index Special Aggregate Indices"
#> 
#> $`36712`$level
#> [1] "0"
#> 
#> $`36712`$children
#> list()

You can extract the tree hierarchy of a deeper element in the table by specifying an element_id. From the previous example, if you wanted to get the subtree for child element 36712 of the Consumer Price Index table:

fredr_release_tables(
  release_id = 10L,
  element_id = 36712L
)
#> # A tibble: 4 × 2
#>   name  value           
#>   <chr> <list>          
#> 1 36713 <named list [9]>
#> 2 36801 <named list [9]>
#> 3 37003 <named list [9]>
#> 4 37691 <named list [9]>
